# 1 Introduction
### 1.1 State of art

Paley-Wiener type theorems, introduced shortly after the celebrated monograph [42] by Paley and Wiener, is a cornerstone approach at the intersection of complex analysis, harmonic analysis, and sampling theory that provides a faithful description of the space of functions or distributions through growth at infinity and the support of their Fourierlike transform.

The classical Paley-Wiener theorem is mainly referred to $L^{2}$-functions with exponential growth rate as $|x+i y| \rightarrow \infty$. Let us denote by $\mathbb{C}^{+}$the upper complex half-space, which can be identified with $\mathbb{C}^{+} \cong \mathbb{R} \times(0,+\infty)$. Then, the Hardy space $H^{2}\left(\mathbb{C}^{+}\right)$consists on analytic functions $F$ on $\mathbb{C}^{+}$with finite norm

$$
\|F\|_{H^{2}\left(\mathbb{C}^{+}\right)}:=\left(\sup _{y>0} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|F(x+i y)|^{2} d x\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

Specifically, the result obtained in [42, Theorem X] (see also [54, Chapter III]) states that the action of the Fourier transform allows us to establish an isometric isomorphism between $H^{2}\left(\mathbb{C}^{+}\right)$and $L^{2}(0,+\infty)$.

Generalizations of Paley-Wiener type theorems can also be obtained for Bernstein spaces $B_{R}^{p}$, with $R>0$ and $1 \leq p \leq \infty$. It is known from [10, p. 98] that $f \in B_{R}^{p}$ if, and only if, $f$ is an entire function satisfying

$$
\|f(\cdot+i y)\|_{p} \leq\|f\|_{p} e^{R|y|}, \quad y \in \mathbb{R}
$$

where $\|\cdot\|_{p}$ denotes the standard $L^{p}$-norm on $\mathbb{R}$.
The Bernstein spaces $B_{R}^{p}$ can be characterized in different ways:
(i) A function $f \in L^{p}(\mathbb{R})$ belongs to $B_{R}^{p}$ if, and only if, its distributional Fourier transform has support $[-R, R]$ in the sense of distributions.
(ii) Let $f \in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$ be such that $f^{(k)} \in L^{p}(\mathbb{R})$, for all $k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$ and some $1 \leq p \leq \infty$. Then, $f \in B_{R}^{p}$ if and only if $f$ satisfies the so-called Bernstein's inequality (cf. [41], p. 116)

$$
\left\|f^{(k)}\right\|_{p} \leq R^{k}\|f\|_{p}, \quad k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}
$$

The subsequent characterization, which establishes the equivalence between Bernstein's inequalities and Bernstein-type spaces, is currently referred to as the real Paley-Wiener type theorems (see, e.g., [1, 3, 4]). This field has been the focus of extensive research by numerous scholars since the seminal contributions of Pesenson [43], Krein-Pesenson [30], Bang [5], and Tuan [55]. One of the primary reasons for this interest is that it can be universally extended to other Fourier-like transforms, whereas the complex Paley-Wiener approach cannot do so (cf. [56, 2, 47, 48]).

In the hypercomplex setting, Kou and Qian made the first successful attempt, documented in their seminal paper [28]. In particular, they showed that the lack of a generalization for the Phragmén-Lindelöf theorem (cf. [10]) to hypercomplex variables did not prevent them from proving their result. Years later, Franklin, Hogan, and Larkin reformulated Kou and Qian's proofs in terms of Bernstein-type spaces in [20]. Recently, Li, Leng, and Fei provided a different approach to real Paley-Wiener spaces in [32].

In the papers [20, 32], the authors use a Clifford-type Fourier transform. This approach first appeared in the context of hypercomplex variables in the seminal paper by Brackx, De Schepper, and Sommen in the mid-2000s (see [13]). It is noteworthy that both papers unjustly overlooked the interplay between Bernstein-type spaces and Bernstein's inequalities. This paper can be seen as a comprehensive exploration of these concepts.

# 1.2 Synopsis 

This paper addresses a hypercomplex version of the Paley-Wiener theorem within the framework developed by Li, McIntosh, and Qian [33], and McIntosh [38]. For a thorough review, see the book by Qian and Li [50]. Our approach also integrates the work of Andersen et al. $[1,2,3,4]$ and Pesenson et al. $[44,45,46,47,48,49]$.

The structure of the paper is as follows. In Section 2, we revise some preliminaries on Clifford algebras and Clifford-valued function spaces. In Section 3, we introduce the fundamental tools of our approach, including the concept of Dirac operators and generalized Hardy and Cauchy-type kernels. We also explain our choice of the Riesz-Hilbert transform and, consequently, the Dirac operator (Subsection 3.1). The two main components of our approach are the following: First, the introduction of the space-fractional Dirac operator

$$
\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}=e^{-\frac{i \pi \theta}{2}}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\left(\cos \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{2}\right)+i \sin \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{2}\right) \mathcal{H}\right)
$$

where $\mathcal{H}$ denotes the Riesz-Hilbert transform. This operator includes not only the Dirac operator $\boldsymbol{D}$ (see (9)), but also the Riesz derivative $(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$ (case $\theta=0$ ) of order $\alpha$ and skewness $\theta$, with $0<\alpha \leq 1$ and $|1-\theta|<\frac{\alpha}{2}$. This extends the pseudo-differential representation of the Dirac operator $\boldsymbol{D}$ (see (3) in Subsection 3.1) as previously considered in the first author's paper [6]; secondly, the formulation of generalized Hardy and Bernstein spaces derived from the Clifford-valued solutions of the subsequent Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$.

Following the introduction of a new class of Dirac-type operators, the subsequent step entails the development of a comprehensive array of novel techniques that have not been addressed by the monogenic theory of Hardy spaces (see [39]). This necessity arises primarily from the absence of a Cauchy integral type formula in the space-fractional setting. To address this critical gap, the generalized Hardy spaces $H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ and the underlying generalized Cauchy kernels $\boldsymbol{E}_{\alpha, n}^{ \pm}$, have been defined and developed in Subsection 3.2 and Subsection 3.3, respectively.

In developing such framework, we have integrated ideas from the following three contemporary research areas:
(I) On the theory of semigroups, the fractional Laplacian of order $\alpha,-(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$, is the generator of the Feller semigroup

$$
\left\{\exp \left(-t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right)\right\}_{t \geq 0}, \text { whereby } 0<\alpha \leq 1 \text { and }|\gamma|<\alpha
$$

(II) On the theory of probability, the so-called Lèvy-Feller diffusion process is uniquely determined, for values of $0<\alpha \leq 1$, by the kernel function

$$
\boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}(\boldsymbol{x}, z)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{n}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} e^{-z|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{n}} e^{i|\boldsymbol{x} \cdot \boldsymbol{\xi}|} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{\xi}, \quad \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, \quad \Re(z)>0
$$

(III) In the theory of singular integral operators, the Riesz-Hilbert transform $\mathcal{H}$ permits us to consider, for every $\boldsymbol{f} \in L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)(1<p<\infty)$, the functions $\boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm}=$ $\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{f} \pm \mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f})$ as the boundary values of Hardy type spaces in the upper and lower half spaces, $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ resp. $\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1}$.
We refer to [19, Chapter IX] and [26, Chapter 4] for an overview of (I), to [9] and the references therein for an overview of (II), and to [39, 38, 50] for an overview of (III). The combination of (I), (II), and (III) in this paper provides a comprehensive framework for dealing with function spaces and distributions. This framework is not limited to power series representations of solutions to the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$, which several authors have previously explored using the Cauchy-Kovalevskaya extension (cf. [15]).

Remark 1 Although statement (III) holds in the borderline cases $p=1$ and $p=\infty$ (cf. [14]), we will focus our analysis in this paper on the range $1<p<\infty$ to avoid further technicalities related to arguments of weak boundedness in BMO type spaces (see [16] and the references therein for an overview). We plan to pursue these cases in a separate paper.

In Section 4, we will consider the generalization of Paley-Wiener theory to the hypercomplex setting, focusing on the solutions of the equation $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ that are generated from the one-parameter semigroup $\left\{e^{-x_{0} \boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}}\right\}_{x_{0} \in \mathbb{R}}$ of exponential type $R^{\alpha}$. The central tenet underpinning our construction is the investigation of the growth behavior of the sequences of functions $\left(\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm}\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}}$, which play the role of the sequence of functions $\left(f^{(k)}\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}}$ generated by the derivatives of $f$ in the one-dimensional setting. It is important to note that these two sequences of Clifford-valued functions are generated from the iterated powers of $\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$ and the boundary values $\boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm}$of the Hardy spaces, as mentioned in (III).

In real Paley-Wiener theory, one typically starts by choosing a real-valued bump function $\boldsymbol{\psi}$ such that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=1$ in $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}$, so that each $\boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm}$can be represented, in the distributional sense, as $\boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm}=\boldsymbol{\psi} * \boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm}$. Such a fact is inherited from the framework considered by Andersen and Jeu in [3] and has been used to simplify parts of the proofs available in most of the literature, including the proofs on the seminal papers by Bang [5] and Tuan [55]. In our concrete case, this serves as a starting point, first in Section 4.1, Theorem 4, to reformulate Andersen's proof [2] on the Hankel transform for Clifford-valued functions which are $r$ adially symmetric, and later, in Subsection 4.2, to extend the Paley-Wiener framework presented by Pesenson-Zayed in [48] and by Pesenson in [49] to the hypercomplex setting.

Although in the case of $r$ adially symmetric functions, the normalized Bessel functions of order $\frac{n}{2}, \boldsymbol{\psi}(\boldsymbol{x})=(R|\boldsymbol{x}|)^{-\frac{n}{2}} J_{\frac{n}{2}}(R|\boldsymbol{x}|)$, seem to be natural candidates for defining compactly supported functions on $\overline{B(0, R)}$ satisfying $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=1$ in $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}$ (cf. [26, p. 118]), it should be emphasized that the existence of $\boldsymbol{\psi}$ is topologically guaranteed by the so-called Uryshon's Lemma (see [34, Exercise 1.15]).

The main result of the paper is in Section 4.2, Theorem 5, where we prove a chain of Paley-Wiener equivalences, which in several papers are called real Paley-Wiener theorems.

As will be demonstrated in Section 5, the tools developed in Section 4 can be used for two purposes: first, to generalize the proof given by Kou and Qian in their paper [28] and to deepen the characterization of Bernstein spaces as presented in [20, Theorem 5.1] (see Theorem 6); Secondly, the tools developed herein can provide more precise information about $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}$ (see Theorem 7).

In the final Section 6, we draw some conclusions and discuss open problems.
Remark 2 In the case where $p=2$, the compactness constraints imposed throughout the paper are not required a priori due to the direct application of Plancherel's theorem (see, for example, [3, Theorem 3.5]). This observation is consistent with the proofs of the PaleyWiener theorem obtained in the works [28, 20], where the condition $\operatorname{supp} \tilde{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, R)}$ was replaced by $\operatorname{supp} \tilde{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq B(0, R)$.

# 2 Preliminaries
### 2.1 Clifford algebras

Let $C \ell_{0, n}$ be the universal Clifford algebra of signature $(0, n)$, generated by the basis $\boldsymbol{e}_{1}, \boldsymbol{e}_{2}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{e}_{n}$ of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. The multiplication in $C \ell_{0, n}$ is induced by the graded anti-commuting relations

$$
\boldsymbol{e}_{j} \boldsymbol{e}_{k}+\boldsymbol{e}_{k} \boldsymbol{e}_{j}=-2 \delta_{j k}, \text { for any } j, k=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

Now, let $\boldsymbol{e}_{A}=\boldsymbol{e}_{j_{1}} \boldsymbol{e}_{j_{2}} \ldots \boldsymbol{e}_{j_{r}}$ be a $r$-multivector of $C \ell_{0, n}$ labeled by the ordered subset $A=\left\{j_{1}, j_{2}, \ldots, j_{r}\right\}$ of $[n]:=\{1,2, \ldots, n\}$, namely

$$
1 \leq j_{1}<j_{2}<\ldots<j_{r} \leq n
$$

In particular, vectors $\boldsymbol{x}=\left(x_{1}, x_{2} \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ and $\boldsymbol{\xi}=\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right)$ of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ are represented through of the linear combinations

$$
\boldsymbol{x}=\sum_{j=1}^{n} x_{j} \boldsymbol{e}_{j} \text { resp. } \boldsymbol{\xi}=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \xi_{j} \boldsymbol{e}_{j}
$$

and the Euclidean inner product $\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle$ between $\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ :

$$
\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle=\sum_{j=1}^{n} x_{j} \xi_{j} \in \mathbb{R}
$$

can be casted in terms of anti-commutator identity, i.e. $\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle=-\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{x} \boldsymbol{\xi}+\boldsymbol{\xi} \boldsymbol{x})$.
By the preceding relation there holds that $\boldsymbol{\xi}^{2}$ is a real number satisfying $\boldsymbol{\xi}^{2}=-|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{2}$, where $|\boldsymbol{\xi}|:=\langle\boldsymbol{\xi}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle^{\frac{1}{2}}$ stands for the Euclidean norm in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. More generally, following [12, Chapter 1], one can endow an inner product by defining it for any $\boldsymbol{\lambda}, \boldsymbol{\mu} \in C \ell_{0, n}$ by

$$
(\boldsymbol{\lambda}, \boldsymbol{\mu})_{0}:=2^{n}\left[\boldsymbol{\lambda} \boldsymbol{\mu}^{\dagger}\right]_{0}=2^{n} \sum_{A} \lambda_{A} \mu_{A}
$$

with $\boldsymbol{\mu}^{\dagger}=\sum_{A} \mu_{A} \overline{e_{A}}$, so that the corresponding norm is given by

$$
|\boldsymbol{\lambda}|_{0}:=\sqrt{(\boldsymbol{\lambda}, \boldsymbol{\lambda})_{0}}=2^{\frac{n}{2}} \sqrt{\left[\boldsymbol{\lambda} \boldsymbol{\lambda}^{\dagger}\right]_{0}}
$$

Hence, $C \ell_{0, n}$ is simultaneously a real/complex Hilbert space and a Banach algebra. For the $|\cdot|_{0}-$ norm, defined as above, one has the identity $\left|\boldsymbol{e}_{0}\right|_{0}=2^{\frac{n}{2}} \neq 1$. Additionally, the following lemma follows straightforwardly.

Lemma 1 For each $\boldsymbol{\lambda}, \boldsymbol{\mu} \in C \ell_{0, n}$, one has the following:
(i) (Submultiplicativity) $|\boldsymbol{\lambda} \boldsymbol{\mu}|_{0} \leq|\boldsymbol{\lambda}|_{0}|\boldsymbol{\mu}|_{0}$
(ii) (Triangle Inequality) $|\boldsymbol{\lambda}+\boldsymbol{\mu}|_{0} \leq|\boldsymbol{\lambda}|_{0}+|\boldsymbol{\mu}|_{0}$.

# Remark 3 

(i) The condition $\left|\boldsymbol{e}_{0}\right|_{0}=2^{\frac{n}{2}}$ is needed to get a Banach algebra. According to L. Ingelstam [25], a Hilbert space with an inner product $(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y})$ is also an associative Banach algebra with identity $\boldsymbol{e}_{0}$, and having a norm $\|\boldsymbol{x}\|=(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{x})^{\frac{1}{2}}$ satisfying $\|\boldsymbol{x} \boldsymbol{y}\| \leq\|\boldsymbol{x}\| \cdot\|\boldsymbol{y}\|$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{e}_{0}\right\|=1$, is called a Hilbert algebra with identity $\boldsymbol{e}_{0}$. A real Hilbert algebra with identity is isomorphic to the real numbers, the complex numbers, or the quaternions. This result excludes the possibility that Clifford algebras, generally, can be Hilbert algebras with identity.
(ii) The standard absolute value of elements in the Clifford algebra $|\lambda|=\sum_{A}\left|\lambda_{A}\right|^{2}$ doesn't fulfill the submultiplicativity condition. Instead of using the factor $2^{\frac{n}{2}}$ we could also define a Clifford operator norm [21].
(iii) The submultiplicativity is needed to prove simple properties of function spaces such as Hölder's or Young's inequality.

As a result, $|\cdot|_{0}$ has the properties of an absolute value. From now on, we will use this absolute value to define Clifford-valued function spaces.

### 2.2 Function spaces

Definition 1 ([12]) $X_{(r)}$ is a unitary right $C \ell_{0, n}$-module, when $\left(X_{(r)},+\right)$ is an abelian group and the mapping $(\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}) \rightarrow \boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{\lambda}$ from $X_{(r)} \times C \ell_{0, n} \rightarrow X_{(r)}$ is defined such that for all $\boldsymbol{\lambda}, \boldsymbol{\mu} \in C \ell_{0, n}$ and $\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g} \in X_{(r)}$ :

1. $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{\lambda}+\boldsymbol{\mu})=\boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{\lambda}+\boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{\mu}$,
2. $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} \boldsymbol{\mu})=(\boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{\lambda}) \boldsymbol{\mu}$,
3. $(\boldsymbol{f}+\boldsymbol{g}) \boldsymbol{\lambda}=\boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{\lambda}+\boldsymbol{g} \boldsymbol{\lambda}$,
4. $\boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{e}_{0}=\boldsymbol{f}$.

Definition 2 A Clifford-valued function $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{A} f_{A}(\boldsymbol{x}) \boldsymbol{e}_{A}$ belongs to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right), 1 \leq p<\infty$, if and only if

$$
\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}:=\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}|\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})|\right|_{0}^{p} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{x})^{\frac{1}{p}}<\infty
$$

## Remark 4

(i) Obviously, all $L^{p}$-spaces are unitary right $C \ell_{0, n}$-modules. It should be mentioned that $\|\cdot\|_{p}$ is a real norm. But it is only a Clifford pseudonorm, because $\|\boldsymbol{\lambda} \boldsymbol{f}\|_{p} \leq|\boldsymbol{\lambda}|_{0}\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}$ for $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in C \ell_{0, n}$.

(ii) The norms $\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}$ and $\left(\sum_{A} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|f_{A}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|^{p} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}$ are equivalent, i.e., a Clifford-valued function $\boldsymbol{f}$ belongs to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$,
$1 \leq p<\infty$, if and only if each component $f_{A}$ belongs to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.
(iii) Functions of these Clifford analogues to the $L^{p}$-spaces fulfil the usual Minkowski's, Hölder's and Young's inequality.

Next, we turn our attention to the inner product structure on a unitary right $C \ell_{0, n^{-}}$ module.
Definition 3 ([12], p. 13) Let $H_{(r)}$ be a unitary right $C \ell_{0, n}$-module. Then, the function $\langle\cdot, \cdot\rangle: H_{(r)} \times H_{(r)} \rightarrow C \ell_{0, n}$ defines an inner product on $H_{(r)}$ if for all $\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}, \boldsymbol{h} \in H_{(r)}$ and $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in C \ell_{0, n}$,

1. $\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}+\boldsymbol{h}\rangle=\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}\rangle+\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{h}\rangle$
2. $\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g} \boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle=\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}\rangle \boldsymbol{\lambda}$
3. $\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}\rangle=\langle\boldsymbol{g}, \boldsymbol{f}\rangle^{\dagger}$
4. $\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{f}\rangle_{0} \in \mathbb{R}_{0}^{+}$and $\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{f}\rangle_{0}=0$ if and only if $\boldsymbol{f}=0$
5. $\langle\boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{\lambda}, \boldsymbol{f} \boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle_{0} \leq|\boldsymbol{\lambda}|_{0}^{2}\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{f}\rangle_{0}$.

The accompanying norm on $H_{(r)}$ is $\|\boldsymbol{f}\|^{2}=\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{f}\rangle_{0}$.
Hence $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ is a unitary right $C \ell_{0, n^{-}}$ module with inner product

$$
\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}\rangle:=2^{n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})^{\dagger} \boldsymbol{g}(\boldsymbol{x}) \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{x}
$$

and the induced norm is

$$
\|\boldsymbol{f}\|^{2}:=\langle\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{f}\rangle_{0}=2^{n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left[\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})^{\dagger} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})\right]_{0} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{x}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}|\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})|_{0}^{2} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{x}=\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{2}^{2}
$$

We start to define the Schwartz spaces as in [23]. Given a multi-index $\alpha=\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{N}_{0}^{n}$, we take the standard multi-index notations

$$
|\alpha|=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \alpha_{j}, \boldsymbol{x}^{\alpha}=\prod_{j=1}^{d} x_{j}^{\alpha_{j}}
$$

and the shorthand notations

$$
\partial^{\alpha}=\frac{\partial^{\alpha_{1}}}{\partial x_{1}^{\alpha_{1}}} \cdots \frac{\partial^{\alpha_{n}}}{\partial x_{n}^{\alpha_{n}}} \quad \text { and } \quad X^{\alpha} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\boldsymbol{x}^{\alpha} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})
$$

for multi-index partial derivative and multiplication operator of order $|\alpha|$, respectively. We define the Clifford Schwartz-type space $\mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ as the set of all Clifford-valued $C^{\infty}$-functions $\boldsymbol{f}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ such that

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial^{\alpha} X^{\beta} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|_{0}<\infty \quad \text { for all } \quad \alpha, \beta \in \mathbb{N}_{0}
$$

Proposition 1 The function $\boldsymbol{f}$ defined by $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{A} f_{A}(\boldsymbol{x}) e_{A}$ belongs to $\mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ if and only if all $f_{A} \in \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.

# 3 Clifford analysis
### 3.1 Dirac operators of Riesz-Feller type

The goal of this subsection is to introduce a hypercomplex analog of the so-called RieszFeller derivative, which corresponds to the space-fractional analog of the Dirac operator

$$
\boldsymbol{D}=\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \boldsymbol{e}_{j} \partial_{x_{j}}
$$

To approach this properly, let us begin by defining the Fourier transform of $\boldsymbol{f} \in \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ and the Fourier inverse of $\boldsymbol{g} \in \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ by

$$
\begin{gathered}
\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi}):=(\mathcal{F} \boldsymbol{f})(\boldsymbol{\xi})=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}) e^{-i\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{x}, \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \\
\left(\mathcal{F}^{-1} \boldsymbol{g}\right)(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{n}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \boldsymbol{g}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) e^{i\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{\xi}, \quad \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}
\end{gathered}
$$

The mapping property $\mathcal{F}: \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ can be extended to $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ by using density arguments, and to the space of tempered distributions $\mathcal{S}^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ by duality arguments.

To draw a parallel with the approach of the first author [6], let us closely examine the Dirac operator $\boldsymbol{D}$, defined by (3), and the Laplace operator

$$
\Delta=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \partial_{x_{j}}^{2}
$$

First, we remember that $\boldsymbol{D}$ and $\Delta$ are connected by the factorization property $\boldsymbol{D}^{2}=$ $-\Delta$. Moreover, we can extend the actions of both operators to spaces of functions and distributions. Namely, for $\boldsymbol{f} \in \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ holds

$$
\mathcal{F}(\boldsymbol{D} \boldsymbol{f})(\boldsymbol{\xi})=-i \boldsymbol{\xi} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \text { and } \mathcal{F}(-\Delta \boldsymbol{f})(\boldsymbol{\xi})=|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{2} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}},(\boldsymbol{\xi}), \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}
$$

The spherical decomposition of the Fourier symbol of $\boldsymbol{D}$ :

$$
-i \boldsymbol{\xi}=|\boldsymbol{\xi}| \frac{-i \boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|}, \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{0\}
$$

together with the set of identities $(-i \boldsymbol{\xi})^{2}=|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{2}$ and $|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha}=\left(|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{2}\right)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$, allows us to determine the pseudo-differential operators $(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$ and $\mathcal{H}:=\boldsymbol{D}(-\Delta)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$ in terms of the Fourier symbols $|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha}$ and $\frac{-i \boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|}$, respectively. More precisely, for $\boldsymbol{f} \in \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ the componentwise actions of $(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \boldsymbol{f}$ and $\mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f}$ are uniquely determined by the spectral formulas

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathcal{F}\left((-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \boldsymbol{f}\right)(\boldsymbol{\xi})=|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi}), \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \\
\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f})(\boldsymbol{\xi})=\frac{-i \boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi}), \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{0\}
\end{gathered}
$$

That is equivalent to $(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}:=\mathcal{F}^{-1}|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha} \mathcal{F}$ resp. $\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{F}^{-1} \frac{-i \boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|} \mathcal{F}$.

The operator $(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$ corresponds to the Riesz derivative of order $\alpha$, while $\mathcal{H}$ represents the hypercomplex generalization of the one-dimensional Riesz transform, due to the unitary property $\boldsymbol{\omega}^{2}=1$ of $\boldsymbol{\omega}:=\frac{-i \boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|}$. We will refer to $\mathcal{H}$ as the Riesz-Hilbert transform (cf. $[7],[24])$.

Based on this, the Dirac operator (3) allows the following pseudo-differential reformulation $\boldsymbol{D}=|\boldsymbol{D}| \operatorname{sgn}(\boldsymbol{D})$,
where $|\boldsymbol{D}|:=(-\Delta)^{\frac{1}{2}}$ is the radial part of $\boldsymbol{D}$ and $\operatorname{sgn}(\boldsymbol{D}):=\mathcal{H}$ is the phase part of $\boldsymbol{D}$ (cf. [38]).

Using the Fourier convolution theorem, both operators can also be expressed as singular integral operators. For $\mathcal{H}$, it is important to emphasize the closed formula (see [33, 38]):

$$
\mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)}{\pi^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} P \cdot V \cdot \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}}{|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}|^{n+1}} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{y}) \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{y}, \quad \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}
$$

This follows from the fact that $\mathcal{H}$ is given by the linear combination

$$
\mathcal{H}=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \boldsymbol{e}_{j} R_{j}, \text { where each } R_{j}:=\mathcal{F}^{-1} \frac{-i \xi_{j}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|} \mathcal{F}
$$

(a directional Riesz transform along the $x_{j}$ axis) admits a singular integral representation in terms of the kernel function (cf. [54, p. 224]):

$$
E_{j}(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)}{\pi^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} \frac{x_{j}}{|\boldsymbol{x}|^{n+1}} \quad, \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{\boldsymbol{0}\} \quad(j=1,2, \ldots, n)
$$

Definition 4 For functions $\boldsymbol{f} \in \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$, the so-called Dirac operator of Riesz-Feller type is defined by the spectral formula

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathcal{F}\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha} \boldsymbol{f}\right)(\boldsymbol{\xi})=|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha} h_{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi}), \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{\boldsymbol{0}\} \\
\text { where } h_{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\xi}):=e^{-\frac{i \pi \theta}{2}}\left(\cos \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{2}\right)+\frac{\boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|} \sin \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{2}\right)\right), \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{\boldsymbol{0}\}
\end{gathered}
$$

Following the standard conventions on Riesz-Feller derivatives, we denote $\alpha$ as the order and $\theta$ as the skewness of $\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$, such that

$$
0<\alpha \leq 1 \mathscr{O}|1-\theta|<\frac{\alpha}{2}
$$

In addition, the operator $\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$, which is defined by (13), allows the pseudo-differential representation

$$
\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}=e^{-\frac{i \pi \theta}{2}}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\left(\cos \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{2}\right)+i \sin \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{2}\right) \mathcal{H}\right)
$$

which includes not only the Dirac operator $\boldsymbol{D}$ (see (9)), but also the Riesz derivative $(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$ (case $\theta=0$ ) and the fractional Riesz-Hilbert transform (limit case $\alpha \rightarrow 0^{+}$), studied in detail by the first author in $[6,7]$.

The operator $\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$ corresponds, up to the phase factor $e^{-\frac{i \pi \theta}{2}}$, to the space-fractional Dirac operator, already considered by the second author in [17]. Throughout the paper,

$\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$ will be referred to as the Dirac operator of Riesz-Feller type because of its several similarities to the one-dimensional Riesz-Feller derivative. For further details, we refer to the paper [37] by Mainardi-Luchko-Pagnini and the references therein.

The study of these operators and their variants, as infinitesimal generators of semigroups, goes back to the operator-theoretical approaches of Bochner [11] and Feller [18], connecting stable distributions with diffusion equations, and has been a source of many fundamental developments in the theory of Hardy spaces in a broad sense (cf. [57]). In addition to its similarity to the polar decomposition underlying complex numbers, it is noteworthy that the choice of $h_{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$ as the phase component of the Clifford vector $\boldsymbol{z}=|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha} h_{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$ holds particular significance in the field of optics.

The definition of $h_{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$ by (14) is derived from the Fourier symbol of the Riesz-Hilbert transform $\mathcal{H}$. This approach parallels the methodology used to derive the fractional Hilbert transform from the Hilbert transform (see [35, 36]). Furthermore, it extends the Fourier symbol of the fractional Hilbert transform in a coherent way, preserving its intrinsic properties $[7,24,8]$. This makes it particularly valuable for analyzing the local orientation, amplitude, and phase of wave functions, as it seamlessly integrates the influences of both near and far fields. The above aspects distinguish our work from much of the existing literature on fractional Dirac operators (see, e.g., [52, 40, 51]). In our study, the optical implementation of the fractional Hilbert transform was crucial and served as the fundamental basis for the pseudo-differential representation of $\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$, provided by (15). We also emphasize that our methodology is in contrast to that proposed by Zayed in [58], where the fractional Fourier transform serves as the basis for constructing a fractional Hilbert transform. Furthermore, this technique is extended to the Riesz transform, allowing the derivation of fractional Riesz transforms; see, for example, [22].

# 3.2 Generalized Hardy spaces $H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}$ 

Let us now consider the Cauchy problem as follows:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\partial_{x_{0}} \boldsymbol{u}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)+\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha} \boldsymbol{u}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=0 & , \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \quad, x_{0} \in \mathbb{R} \backslash\{0\} \\
\boldsymbol{u}(\boldsymbol{x}, 0)=\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}) & , \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \\
\lim _{|x_{0}| \rightarrow+\infty} \boldsymbol{u}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=0 & , \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}
\end{array}\right.
$$

To study it from a Hardy space point of view, we need to define appropriate function spaces that capture the order and skewness parameters, $\alpha$ and $\theta$, of $\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$ on the upper and lower half-spaces, $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ and $\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1}$, of $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. First and foremost, set

$$
L^{p, \pm}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)=\left\{\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{f} \pm \mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f}): \boldsymbol{f} \in L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)\right\}
$$

We recall that

$$
\frac{1}{2}(I+\mathcal{H})=\mathcal{F}^{-1} \chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \mathcal{F}, \quad \frac{1}{2}(I-\mathcal{H})=\mathcal{F}^{-1} \chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \mathcal{F}
$$

where $\chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$ and $\chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$ represent the Fourier symbols

$$
\chi_{ \pm}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=\frac{1}{2}\left(1 \pm \frac{i \boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|}\right), \quad \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{\boldsymbol{0}\}
$$

Based on this, the following reformulation of (15) in terms of $\frac{1}{2}(I \pm \mathcal{H})$, given by

$$
\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}=(-\boldsymbol{\Delta})^{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \frac{1}{2}(I+\mathcal{H})+e^{-i \pi \theta}(-\boldsymbol{\Delta})^{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \frac{1}{2}(I-\mathcal{H})
$$

is obtained by reformulating the Fourier symbol (14) as a linear combination of the symbols (18). That is, $h_{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=\chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi})+e^{-i \theta \pi} \chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$.

On the other hand, considering the properties (cf. [33, p. 671] \& [38, subsection 5.2.1]) associated with the Fourier symbols

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi})+\chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=1, & \\
\left(\chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi})\right)^{2}=\chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi}), & \left(\chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi})\right)^{2}=\chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi}), \\
\chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=0, & \chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=0
\end{array}
$$

it follows that $\frac{1}{2}(I \pm \mathcal{H})$ are projection operators, leading to the direct sum decomposition

$$
L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)=L^{p,+}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right) \oplus L^{p,-}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)
$$

This allows us to consider the $L^{p, \pm}$-spaces (16) as hypercomplex analogues of the Hardy spaces over $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Furthermore, with the help of the following analytic semigroups

$$
\left\{\exp \left(-x_{0} e^{i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right)\right\}_{x_{0} \geq 0} \text { resp. }\left\{\exp \left(-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right)\right\}_{x_{0} \leq 0}
$$

we can extend it to the upper and lower half-spaces, $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ and $\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1}$, respectively, of $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. This leads to the following definition:

Definition 5 (Generalized Hardy spaces $H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}$ ) Let $0<\alpha \leq 1, \beta \in \mathbb{R}$ and $1<p<$ $\infty$ be given. We define $H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ and $H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ as follows:

1. In case of $|\beta|<\frac{\alpha}{2}, \boldsymbol{u}_{+} \in H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ if, and only if:
a) $\boldsymbol{u}_{+}$is defined by

$$
\boldsymbol{u}_{+}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=\exp \left(-x_{0} e^{i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right) \boldsymbol{f}_{+}(\boldsymbol{x}), \quad\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1}
$$

for some $\boldsymbol{f}_{+} \in L^{p,+}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$.
b) $\sup _{x_{0}>0}\left\|\boldsymbol{u}_{+}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right\|_{p}<\infty$.
2. In case of $|1-\beta|<\frac{\alpha}{2}, \boldsymbol{u}_{-} \in H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ if, and only if:
a) $\boldsymbol{u}_{-}$is defined by

$$
\boldsymbol{u}_{-}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=\exp \left(-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right) \boldsymbol{f}_{-}(\boldsymbol{x}), \quad\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1}
$$

for some $\boldsymbol{f}_{-} \in L^{p,-}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$.
b) $\sup _{x_{0}<0}\left\|\boldsymbol{u}_{-}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right\|_{p}<\infty$.

Remark 5 From the limit conditions

$$
\lim _{x_{0} \rightarrow 0^{+}} \boldsymbol{u}_{+}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=\boldsymbol{f}_{+}(\boldsymbol{x}) \quad \text { ํ } \quad \lim _{x_{0} \rightarrow 0^{-}} \boldsymbol{u}_{-}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=\boldsymbol{f}_{-}(\boldsymbol{x})
$$

it holds that $\boldsymbol{f}_{+}=\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{f}+\mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f})$ and $\boldsymbol{f}_{-}=\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{f}-\mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f})$ are the boundary values of the generalized Hardy spaces $H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ and $H_{\alpha, \beta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$, respectively.

The generalized Hardy spaces introduced above have a crucial property: they allow a complete characterization of the solutions of the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$, as detailed below.
Proposition 2 For values of $0<\alpha \leq 1,|1-\theta|<\frac{\alpha}{2}$ and $1<p<\infty$, we assume that $\boldsymbol{f} \in L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$. We also assume that

$$
\boldsymbol{u}_{+} \in H_{\alpha, 0}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right) \quad \text { ํ } \quad \boldsymbol{u}_{-} \in H_{\alpha, \theta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)

where $H_{\alpha, 0}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ and $H_{\alpha, \theta}^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ correspond to the generalized Hardy spaces introduced in Definition 5. Then, the function $\boldsymbol{u}$ defined by

$$
\boldsymbol{u}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}

\boldsymbol{u}_{-}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) & , \quad\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1} \\

solves the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ if, and only if, $\boldsymbol{u}_{+}$(case of $\beta=0$ ) and $\boldsymbol{u}_{-}$(case of $\beta=\theta$ ) are solutions of

$$

$$

Proof: Starting from (13), we recall that the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ in the Fourier domain is given by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{ll}

where

$$
h_{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=\chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi})+e^{-i \theta \pi} \chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi}), \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=(\mathcal{F} \boldsymbol{f})(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \& \widehat{\boldsymbol{u}}\left(\boldsymbol{\xi}, x_{0}\right)=\left(\mathcal{F} \boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right)(\boldsymbol{\xi})

and

$$

\lim _{x_{0} \rightarrow 0^{-}} \chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \widehat{\boldsymbol{u}}\left(\boldsymbol{\xi}, x_{0}\right)=\chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) & , \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{\boldsymbol{0}\} \\

for almost all $\boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \in \backslash\{\boldsymbol{0}\}$, is derived from the exponential decay of $e^{-x_{0}|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha}}$, for values of $x_{0}>0$, while for values of $x_{0}<0$ and $|1-\theta|<\frac{\alpha}{2}$, the limit conditions are

for almost all $\boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, resulting in $\left|e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \theta|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha}}}\right|=e^{-x_{0} \cos (\pi \theta)|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha}}$.

# 3.3 Cauchy type kernels $E_{\alpha, n}^{ \pm}$ 

The characterization of solutions to the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$, as established in Proposition 2, provides a groundbreaking framework for studying fractional analogues of the Cauchy kernel.

$$
\boldsymbol{E}(\boldsymbol{x}, t)=\frac{1}{2 \omega_{n}} \frac{t+\boldsymbol{x}}{\left(t^{2}+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right) \frac{n+1}{2}}, \quad(\boldsymbol{x}, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1}
$$

building on Feller's influential technique [18] for stable distributions (see [19, Chapter VI] for an overview). Here and elsewhere, the constant $\omega_{n}=\frac{\pi^{\frac{n+1}{2}}}{\Gamma\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)}$, which represents the measure of the unit sphere $\mathbb{S}^{n}$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$.

Following the line of reasoning considered by the second author in [17], let us define it by

$$
\boldsymbol{E}_{\alpha, n}^{ \pm}(\boldsymbol{x}, z)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}(\boldsymbol{x}, z) \pm \mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}(\boldsymbol{x}, z)\right), \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, \Re(z)>0
$$

where $\boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}(\boldsymbol{x}, z)$ denotes the radially symmetric kernel function given by

$$
\boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}(\boldsymbol{x}, z)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{n}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} e^{-z|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha}} e^{i\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{\xi}, \quad \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, \quad \Re(z)>0
$$

When $\alpha=1$, the set of the identities

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\boldsymbol{E}_{1, n}^{+}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=\boldsymbol{E}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right), & \left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} \\
\boldsymbol{E}_{1, n}^{-}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)=-\boldsymbol{E}\left(\boldsymbol{x},-x_{0}\right), & \left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{-}^{n+1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

result from the Fourier inversion formulas (cf. [54, Theorem 1.14])

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{F}^{-1}\left(e^{-t|\cdot|}\right)(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2 \omega_{n}} \frac{t}{\left(t^{2}+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} & ,(\boldsymbol{x}, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} \\
\frac{1}{2} \mathcal{F}^{-1}\left(e^{-t|\cdot|} \frac{-i\langle\cdot\rangle)}{|\cdot|}\right)(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2 \omega_{n}} \frac{\boldsymbol{x}}{\left(t^{2}+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} & ,(\boldsymbol{x}, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

The Poisson kernel $\boldsymbol{K}_{1, n}\left(\boldsymbol{x},\left|x_{0}\right|\right)=\boldsymbol{E}\left(\boldsymbol{x},\left|x_{0}\right|\right)+\boldsymbol{E}\left(-\boldsymbol{x},\left|x_{0}\right|\right)$, as encoded in the set of identities (30), has also been considered in applications involving Brownian motion to describe a Cauchy probability distribution law in the upper half space $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1}$, from the north pole of the $n$-dimensional unit sphere $\mathbb{S}^{n}$, as detailed in the papers by Letac [31] and Kato-McCullagh [27] on conformal probability distributions. Since our current understanding of probability is not sufficient to discuss this on a technical level, we will rely solely on Feller's account [18] to establish a concrete connection between the Cauchy kernels (28) and the one-parameter semigroup $\left\{e^{-x_{0} \boldsymbol{D}_{0}^{\alpha}}\right\}_{x_{0} \in \mathbb{R}}$ generated by $-\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$.

In a broad sense, for $z=t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}$ we can interpret the Fourier transform of the kernel function $\boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}$, defined by (29), as a stable distribution on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ with index $\alpha$ and skewness $\gamma$, where $0<\alpha \leq 1$ and $|\gamma|<\alpha$ (cf. [9, 37]). Namely, if

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{K}}_{\alpha, n}(\boldsymbol{\xi}, z)=e^{-z|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha}}, \quad \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, \quad \Re(z)>0
$$

represents the characteristic function of a symmetric stable process $\{\boldsymbol{X}(z): \Re(z)>0\}$, it turns out that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{K}}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{\xi}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)$ solves the Cauchy problem

$$
\begin{cases}\partial_{t} \widehat{\boldsymbol{K}}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{\xi}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)+e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha} \widehat{\boldsymbol{K}}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{\xi}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)=0 & ,(\boldsymbol{\xi}, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} \widehat{\boldsymbol{K}}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{\xi}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)=1 & , \boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}\end{cases}
$$

Thus, by taking the Fourier inverse on both sides of (32), it turns out that (29) provides an integral representation of the fundamental solution of the space-fractional operator $\partial_{t}+e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$. That is, $\boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)$ solves

$$
\begin{cases}\partial_{t} \boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)+e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)=0 & ,(\boldsymbol{x}, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n+1} \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} \boldsymbol{K}_{\alpha, n}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right)=\delta(\boldsymbol{x}) & , \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}\end{cases}
$$

where $\delta$ is the delta function on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$.
The previous identity allows us to represent, in the distributional sense, the analytic semigroup of Lévy-Feller type, $\left\{\exp \left(-t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right)\right\}_{t \geq 0}$, with the parameters $0<\alpha \leq 1$ and $|\gamma|<\alpha$, by the convolution formula

$$
\exp \left(-t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right) \boldsymbol{f}=\mathbf{K}_{\alpha, n}\left(\cdot, t e^{\frac{i \pi \gamma}{2}}\right) * \boldsymbol{f}

### 4.1 The radially symmetric case

First, for each $k, \ell \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$ and $\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, let us take a closer look at the integral representation of a radially symmetric function $\boldsymbol{\psi} \in \mathcal{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ :

$$
|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2 \ell}\left((-\Delta)^{\frac{n}{2}}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{\psi}(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{n}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left(-\Delta_{\boldsymbol{\xi}}\right)^{\ell}\left(|\boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha k} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})\right) e^{i\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{\xi}
$$

where $\Delta_{\boldsymbol{\xi}}$ is the Laplace operator on the variable $\boldsymbol{\xi}$. In terms of the polar coordinates $\rho=|\boldsymbol{\xi}|$ and $\boldsymbol{\omega}=\frac{\boldsymbol{\xi}}{|\boldsymbol{\xi}|}\left(\boldsymbol{\xi} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{\boldsymbol{0}\}\right)$, we get the split

$$
\Delta_{\boldsymbol{\xi}}=\frac{d^{2}}{d \rho^{2}}+\frac{n-1}{\rho} \frac{d}{d \rho}+\frac{1}{\rho^{2}} \Delta_{\mathbb{S}^{n-1}}
$$

where $\Delta_{\mathbb{S}^{n-1}}$ stands for the Laplace-Beltrami operator on the $(n-1)$-dimensional sphere $\mathbb{S}^{n-1}$.

An important property of $\Delta_{\boldsymbol{\xi}}$ is that it maps radially symmetric functions to radially symmetric functions. Furthermore, based on the following Fourier inversion formula for radially symmetric functions $\varphi$ :

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \varphi(|\boldsymbol{\xi}|) e^{i\langle\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{\xi}\rangle} d \boldsymbol{\xi}=\frac{(2 \pi)^{\frac{n}{2}}}{|\boldsymbol{x}|^{\frac{n-2}{2}}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \varphi(\rho) \rho^{\frac{n}{2}} J_{\frac{n}{2}-1}(\rho|\boldsymbol{x}|) d \rho
$$

there holds the following equivalent representation for (39):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\boldsymbol{x}|^{2 \ell}\left((-\Delta)^{\frac{n}{2}}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{\psi}(\boldsymbol{x})= \\
& =\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{\frac{n}{2}}} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left(-\widetilde{\Delta}_{\frac{n}{2}-1}\right)^{\ell}\left(\rho^{\alpha k} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}(\rho)\right) \frac{J_{\frac{n}{2}-1}(\rho|\boldsymbol{x}|)}{(\rho|\boldsymbol{x}|)^{\frac{n}{2}-1}} \rho^{n-1} d \rho
\end{aligned}
$$

$J_{\lambda}$ stands for the Bessel function of order $\lambda$ and

$$
\widetilde{\Delta}_{\lambda}:=\frac{d^{2}}{d \rho^{2}}+\frac{2 \lambda+1}{\rho} \frac{d}{d \rho}
$$

for the Bessel operator of order $\lambda$, with $\lambda>-\frac{1}{2}$.
Thus, the integral representation (42) provides an effective approach to deriving a real Paley-Wiener theorem by real variable methods. The following theorem can be interpreted as a reformulation of [2, Theorem 3] for Clifford valued functions that are radially symmetric.

$$

satisfies the $\lim \sup -$ condition $\lim \sup _{k \rightarrow \infty}(\phi_{k}(R))^{\frac{1}{k}}=R^{\alpha}$, we can deduce from the properties of $\lim \sup$ that the inequality (44) holds for the constant $\Lambda_{m, n}$, as given above.

\end{aligned}
$$

where $\chi_{-}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$ and $\chi_{+}(\boldsymbol{\xi})$ denote the idempotents defined by (18) (see also (17)). Then, by applying Hölder's inequality, we derive the following set of inequalities:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left.(R+\varepsilon)^{\alpha k}\left|\chi_{\mp}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})\right|_{0} \leq\right| \boldsymbol{\xi}|^{\alpha k}\left|\chi_{\mp}(\boldsymbol{\xi}) \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})\right|_{0} \leq\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm} * \boldsymbol{\psi}\right\|_{1} \\

$$

holds for every $k$ in $\mathbb{N}_{0}$.

where $B$ denotes a continuous function $B: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow(0,+\infty)$.

Thus, by straightforward computation, we establish that (48) is equivalent to the set of inequalities provided by the statement (B), as intended.

# 5 Generalized Bernstein spaces and spectral analysis
### 5.1 Generalized Bernstein spaces $\mathcal{S B}_{R}^{p}$

We begin this section with the definition of the generalized Bernstein space generated by $\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$, which serves as a function space that seamlessly describes the null solutions of $\partial_{x_{0}}+\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}$ that are of exponential type $R^{\alpha}$. The generalization of Bernstein-type spaces begins with the solutions of the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$, as outlined in Proposition 3. This problem is closely related to the approach of Pesenson [46, 47, 49] and Pesenson-Zayed [48] on abstract Paley-Wiener spaces.

Definition 6 (Generalized Bernstein spaces $\mathcal{S B}_{R}^{p}$ ) For $R>0$ and $1<p<\infty$, the generalized Bernstein space $\mathcal{S B}_{R}^{p}\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ is a Banach right module consisting of all Cliffordvalued functions $\boldsymbol{u}$ such that:
(1) $\boldsymbol{u}$ is the solution of $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ provided by Proposition 3;
(2) $\boldsymbol{u}(\cdot, 0)=\boldsymbol{f}$ belongs to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$;
(3) $\sup _{x_{0} \in \mathbb{R}} e^{-\left|x_{0}\right| R^{\alpha}}\left\|\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right\|_{p}<\infty$.

### 5.2 An hypercomplex analogue of the Paley-Wiener theorem

Let us now turn our attention to the hypercomplex version of the Paley-Wiener theorem. By merging Proposition 4 and Theorem 6, we are now able to obtain a generalization of [28, Theorem 2.1] and [20, Theorem 5.1]. In particular, we can generalize the following chain of equivalences:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}} e^{-\left|x_{0}+\boldsymbol{x}\right| R}\left|\boldsymbol{u}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)\right|<\infty & \Longleftrightarrow \operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, R)} \\
& \Longleftrightarrow \boldsymbol{u} \in \mathcal{S B}_{R}^{2}(\boldsymbol{D})
\end{aligned}
$$

In this context and beyond, we will use the notation $\left|x_{0}+\boldsymbol{x}\right|:=\sqrt{x_{0}^{2}+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}}$ to represent the norm of the paravector $x_{0}+\boldsymbol{x}$ in $C \ell_{0, n}$.

Theorem 6 Let $\boldsymbol{u}$ be the solution of the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ such that

$$
\boldsymbol{u}(\cdot, 0)=\boldsymbol{f} \quad \text { and } \quad \boldsymbol{f} \in L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)
$$

For $1<p<\infty$ and $R>0$, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, R)}$.
(b) $\sup _{\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}} e^{-\left|x_{0}+\boldsymbol{x}\right| R^{\alpha}}\left|\boldsymbol{u}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)\right|_{0}<\infty$.
(c) $\boldsymbol{u} \in \mathcal{S B}_{R}^{p}\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$.

Then, the equivalence $(A) \Longleftrightarrow(C)$ provided by Theorem 5 , Sec. 4.2, allows us to establish the equivalence

$$
\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, R)} \Longleftrightarrow \sup _{x_{0} \in \mathbb{R}} e^{-\left|x_{0}\right| R^{\alpha}}\left\|\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right\|_{p} \leq C
$$

for some $0<C<\infty$, thereby proving the equivalence between (a) and (c).

Then, by Lemma 2 , there exists a real-valued bump function $\boldsymbol{\psi}$ such that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=1$ in $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}$. From Proposition 3, we get the identity

$$
\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)= \begin{cases}\left(e^{-x_{0}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}\right) * \boldsymbol{f}_{+} & , x_{0}>0 \\ \left(e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \theta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}\right) * \boldsymbol{f}_{-} & , x_{0}<0 \\ \boldsymbol{f} & , x_{0}=0\end{cases}
$$

is valid at the level of the distributions, where $\boldsymbol{f}_{ \pm}=\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{f} \pm \mathcal{H} \boldsymbol{f})$. As a result, for each $x_{0} \in \mathbb{R} \backslash\{0\}$, we get

$$
\left|\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right|_{0} \leq \begin{cases}\left\|e^{-x_{0}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}\right\|_{q}\left\|\boldsymbol{f}_{+}\right\|_{p} & , x_{0}>0 \\ \left\|e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \theta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}\right\|_{q}\left\|\boldsymbol{f}_{-}\right\|_{p} & , x_{0}<0\end{cases}
$$

with $1<p, q<\infty$ such that $\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}=1$, it follows by Hölder's inequality.
Next, let us take a close look at the family of norms $\left\|e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}\right\|_{q}$, with $\beta \in$ $\{0, \theta\}$. By choosing a constant $m \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$ such that $\left\|\left(1+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{-m}\right\|_{q}<\infty$ and observing that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}\right\|_{q}^{q}= \\
=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left(1+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{-m q}\left|\left(1+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{m} e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|_{0}^{q} \boldsymbol{d} \boldsymbol{x}

we obtain

$$
\left\|e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \theta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}\right\|_{q} \leq S_{\beta}\left\|\left(1+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{-m}\right\|_{q}
$$

where

$$
S_{\beta}=\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\left(1+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{m} e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}} \boldsymbol{\psi}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|_{0}
$$

Furthermore, recalling that the formal Taylor series expansion of $e^{-x_{0} e^{-i \pi \beta}(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}}$ is absolutely convergent, it follows that

$$
S_{\beta} \leq \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{\left|x_{0}\right|^{k}}{k!} \boldsymbol{s}_{k} \quad, \text { with } \quad \boldsymbol{s}_{k}=\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\left(1+|\boldsymbol{x}|^{2}\right)^{m}\left((-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{\psi}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|_{0}
$$

Following Theorem 4, it can be deduced that the coefficients $\boldsymbol{s}_{k}$ are bounded above by $\Lambda_{m, n} R^{\alpha k}$. As a result,

$$
S_{\beta} \leq \Lambda_{m, n} e^{\left|x_{0}\right| R^{\alpha}} \leq \Lambda_{m, n} e^{\left|x_{0}+\boldsymbol{x}\right| R^{\alpha}}
$$

for all $\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and $\beta \in\{0, \theta\}$.
Moreover, the direct combination of the estimates (50) and (49), followed by the mapping property $\mathcal{H}: L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ (cf. [54, Theorem 2.6]), provides the proof of statement (b).

Proof: $\left[\operatorname{Proof}$ of $(\mathrm{b}) \Longrightarrow(\mathrm{a})\right]$ Let us choose a real-valued bump function $\boldsymbol{\psi} \in \mathbb{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$ such that $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\psi}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, R)}$ and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=1$ in $\overline{B(0, R)}$. $$
\left|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{u}_{ \pm}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right)\right|_{0}=\left|\boldsymbol{u}_{ \pm}\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) *\left((-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{\psi}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|_{0} \quad,\left(\boldsymbol{x}, x_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{ \pm}^{n+1}

$$

$$

where $\vartheta_{m, n}^{+}$and $\vartheta_{m, n}^{-}$are continuous functions $\vartheta_{m, n}^{ \pm}: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow(0,+\infty)$ defined by

# 5.3 Spectral analysis 

Next, we explicitly determine the maximal radius $R$ for which $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, R)}$. This determination is achieved by generalizing the Landau-Kolmogorov-Stein inequality that underlies the Favard constants (cf. [53]). The latter are defined as follows:

$$
K_{j}=\frac{4}{\pi} \sum_{r=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{r(j+1)}}{(2 r+1)^{j+1}}(j \in \mathbb{N})
$$

Therefore, an explicit formula for the maximal radius can be easily derived, analogous to the real Paley-Wiener theory (cf. [3, Theorem 2.6]). This result follows from the analysis of the growth of the sequence of Clifford-valued functions $\left(\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}}$.

The following result, a hypercomplex analog of the result of [48, Lemma 6], serves as the basis for the following analysis.

Lemma 4 (Landau-Kolmogorov-Stein type inequality) For each $\boldsymbol{f} \in L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; C \ell_{0, n}\right)$, one has the following inequality

$$
\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\ell} \leq C_{k, \ell}\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}^{\ell-k}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{\ell} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{k}, \quad 0 \leq k \leq \ell
$$

where $C_{k, \ell}$ represents the constant $\frac{\left(K_{\ell-k}\right)^{\ell}}{\left(K_{\ell}\right)^{\ell-k}}$.
Proof: Starting from Landau-Kolmogorov-Stein's inequality (cf. [53, PART II]), we observe that

$$
\left\|\left(\partial_{x_{0}}\right)^{k} \phi\right\|_{\infty}^{\ell} \leq C_{k, \ell}\|\phi\|_{\infty}^{\ell-k}\left\|\left(\partial_{x_{0}}\right)^{\ell} \phi\right\|_{\infty}^{k}
$$

yields for the analytic type function $\phi$, defined via

$$
\phi\left(x_{0}\right)=\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right), \boldsymbol{g}\right\rangle_{0} \quad, x_{0} \in \mathbb{R}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{u}$ is the solution of the Cauchy problem $\left(\mathcal{C P}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)$ given by the Proposition 3. This is equivalent to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left\langle\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k}\left(\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right), \boldsymbol{g}\right\rangle_{0}\right\|_{\infty}^{\ell} & \leq C_{k, \ell}\left\|\left\langle\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right), \boldsymbol{g}\right\rangle_{0}\right\|_{\infty}^{\ell-k} \\
& \times\left\|\left\langle\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{\ell}\left(\boldsymbol{u}\left(\cdot, x_{0}\right)\right), \boldsymbol{g}\right\rangle_{0}\right\|_{\infty}^{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\left|\left\langle\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}\right\rangle_{0}\right|^{\ell} \leq C_{k, \ell}\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}^{\ell-k}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{\ell} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{k}\left\|\boldsymbol{g}\right\|_{q}^{\ell}

$$
\boldsymbol{g}(\boldsymbol{x})=\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}) \frac{\left|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|_{0}^{p-2}}{\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{\ell} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{p-1}}

we also get (56). This proves our claim.

This implies that

$$
\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}} \leq\left\|\boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{\frac{\ell}{\alpha k}}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}} \liminf _{\ell \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{\ell} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha \ell}}
$$

Furthermore, if we take $\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty}$ on both sides of the above inequality, we get

$$
\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}} \leq \liminf _{\ell \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{\ell} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha \ell}}
$$

which shows that the limit (57) exists.
Next, we prove that $R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})$, defined by (58), is an upper bound of the limit (57). To do this, we observe that, given the statement (B) of Theorem 5, one has the inequality

$$
\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}} \leq C^{\frac{1}{k}} R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})\left\|\boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{\frac{\ell}{\alpha k}}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}
$$

for some $0<C<\infty$.
Then, by taking the limit $k \rightarrow \infty$ of both sides of the above inequality, we conclude that

$$
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}} \leq R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})
$$

Now, to prove that the limit (57) coincides with (58), we assume by contradiction that

$$
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}<R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})
$$

Then there exist $\sigma>0$ and $M>0$ such that

$$
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}<\sigma<R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}}) \quad \& \quad\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p} \leq M \sigma^{\alpha k}\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}
$$

So by the statement (A) of the Theorem 5 we get $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, \sigma)}$, which contradicts the definition (58) of $R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})$.

Conversely, let us assume that the limit (57) exists and is finite. This means that

$$
\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}=\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}
$$

Then there exists $R>0$ such that the Bernstein type inequality, which appears in statement (B) of Theorem 5, holds. Thus, according to statement (A) of Theorem 5, this is equivalent to saying that $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\boldsymbol{f}} \subseteq \overline{B(0, R)}$.
Then, from the definition (58) of $R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})$, it immediately follows that the inequality

$$
\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p} \leq C\left(R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})\right)^{\alpha k}\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}
$$

holds for every $k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$, is equivalent to

$$
\frac{\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}}{C^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}}} \leq R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})
$$

Furthermore, by allowing $k \rightarrow \infty$ on both sides of the above inequality, we get

$$
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{D}_{\theta}^{\alpha}\right)^{k} \boldsymbol{f}\right\|_{p}^{\frac{1}{\alpha k}} \leq R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})
$$

Finally, the proof that the left side of the above inequality is indeed equal to $R(\widehat{\boldsymbol{f}})$ is obtained by applying the contradiction argument outlined previously.

abstract:
This paper explores Paley-Wiener type theorems within the framework of
hypercomplex variables. The investigation focuses on a space-fractional version
of the Dirac operator $\mathbf{D}_\theta^{\alpha}$ of order $\alpha$ and
skewness $\theta$. The pseudo-differential reformulation of
$\mathbf{D}_\theta^{\alpha}$ in terms of the Riesz derivative
$(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$ and the so-called {\textit Riesz-Hilbert
transform} $H$, allows for the description of generalized Hardy spaces on the
upper and lower half-spaces of $\mathbf{R}^{n+1}$, $\mathbf{R}^{n+1}_+$ resp.
$\mathbb{R}^{n+1}_-$, using L\'evy-Feller type semigroups generated by
$-(-\Delta)^{\frac{\alpha}{2}}$, and the boundary values
$\mathbf{f}_\pm=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{f}\pm H\mathbf{f}\right)$.
  Subsequently, we employ a proof strategy rooted in {\textit real Paley-Wiener
methods} to demonstrate that the growth behavior of the sequences of functions
$\left(\left(\mathbf{D}_\theta^{\alpha}\right)^k\mathbf{f}_{\pm}\right)_{k\in
\mathbb{N}_0}$ effectively captures the relationship between the support of the
Fourier transform $\widehat{\mathbf{f}}$ of the $L^p-$function $\mathbf{f}$, in
the case where $\mathrm{supp}\widehat{\mathbf{f}}\subseteq \overline{B(0,R)}$,
and the solutions of Cauchy problems equipped with the space-time operator
$\partial_{x_0} + \mathbf{D}_\theta^{\alpha}$, which are of exponential type
$R^\alpha$.
  Within the developed framework, introducing a hypercomplex analog for the
Bernstein spaces $B_R^p$ arises naturally, allowing for the meaningful
extension of the results by Kou and Qian as well as Franklin, Hogan, and
Larkin. Specifically, leveraging the established Stein-Kolmogorov inequalities
for hypercomplex variables enables us to accurately determine the maximum
radius $R$ for which $\operatorname{supp}\widehat{\mathbf{f}} \subseteq
\overline{B(0, R)}$ holds.
